instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_RIGHT: What is SMC_LID_RIGHT? SMC_LID_RIGHT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the right LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_RIGHT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Bad to worse
threads.message:
Repair attempt 1: 
Recently fixed this one after minor water damage. Replaced the RIO because of crackling sound. Tested it, everything seemed to work.

Repair attempt 2: 
Got it back because it wouldn't wake up on occasion. Measure around for a bit and found <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LID_OPEN_RIGHT</SIGNAL> to be .45V when the MB was open. This should be 1,5v on a normal board. Ended up tying <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> left and right together to ensure <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> going to 1,5v when open. I have my doubts about this fix, but seemed to work at the time. 

Repair attempt 3:
MacBook turned off suddenly according to the customer. When I got it, the charger showed 20v with amps jumping from 0 to .08 and back and the T2 chip felt a bit warm to the touch and of course no boot. After removing the aforementioned jumper and ultrasonic, now the board is stuck on 5v charging, again cycling between 0 and 0.08A. LDO's measure fine, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present. With the jumper removed and just the bare board, <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> and LEFT both are at 1,5v with nothing connected (as before).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Bad to worse
threads.message:
Something happened on USB-C areas.
All the ports have the same behaviour?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Bad to worse
threads.message: No, <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> area looked clean before ultrasonic. All ports act the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Bad to worse
threads.message:
Did you use sweep option on ultrasonic process.
Be aware, ultrasonic cleaner can knock off components, or break traces.
Sweep option must be used, to avoid hot-spots.

Do you get 1V1 LDO at both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Bad to worse
threads.message: Yes, it sweeps, not optional on mine. 1V1 missing on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, present on the other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Bad to worse
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Bad to worse
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Bad to worse
threads.message:
Any feedback about the solution?
Was bad <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Bad to worse
threads.message:
Yes, that's what I meant to say: changing <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> fixed it. 

Strange one because all earlier problems had nothing to do with the cd3215s. Must have been some corrosion I missed or something.
